Her performance is brilliant - quick, spirited, but natural. She typifies the New York Italian, so common in film, without being a caricature. As for Pesci, I think he's one of Hollywood's most versatile but under-rated actors. To think that this is the same man who plays the psycho hit-man in Good Fellas! As for other performances, they are all excellent. F. Scott Fitzgerald said something to the effect that tragedy makes us feel, while comedy makes us think. Hopefully I'm not spoiling things by saying this, but I find myself dwelling on the movie and on the position it takes, whether inadvertent or intentional, on capital punishment. I keep wondering whether director Lynn and writer Launer want to make a statement with their film. Whatever, if you're looking for a funny movie to watch, My Cousin Vinny will have you laughing.
My Cousin Vinny is such an awesome movie, with a great story, an all-star cast, surprises, comedy, drama and so much American South culture, both factual and fictional.

reviews.review_title: One of the funniest films I have ever seen.
reviews.content: 10/10First 20 minutes in and I am already laughing out loud. An amazing comedy film that hits all the right nodes. I am glad that I decided to watch this.The story is simple and told in a simple manner. What really worked for me was the laid back way the film was handled. Even something as serious as a murder charge felt like no big deal. The acting was on point by all the cast. Even though it was released in 1992, it does not feel very old.What an incredible performance by Joe Pesci. It never felt like he was acting. The subtle expressions, the body language and the laid back approach everything about Vinny Gambini felt real. Marisa Tomei as Miss Vito was really good. She was very funny with her little back and forth with Vinny. I can't believe she is Aunt May.There is something wholesome about the film. It feels shooting. I loved the film and I don't think I have laughed so much to any recent films. Recommended.

reviews.review_title: Some great moments in a sea of mediocrity
reviews.content: Despite having been made in 1992, My Cousin Vinny has a distinct 80's feel in its first half - I'm not sure if it's the mere presence of Ralph Macchio, or the staggering amount of mistaken-identity gags (three of them in the first twenty minutes, none of which has any real point). As long as Macchio and Whitfield are the center of the film, it's achingly bad comedy. Thankfully, the movie does get into its element once it turns into a courtroom farce, when Joe Pesci and especially Marisa Tomei take center stage and allow their characters to grow. They're not great characters or very clever ones - how Tomei won that Oscar over Judy Davis and Vanessa Redgrave is a bit of a mystery - but they both do a commendable job with their roles, and make the second half of the movie watchable and even very entertaining, but still completely forgettable.
Great movie with a very satisfying ending. I highly suggest watching if you haven't.

"My Cousin Vinny" is a very entertaining comedy. The film has about three or four absolutely hilarious scenes and it is always entertaining even if it's perhaps twenty minutes too long. Of course, Marisa Tomei was really good as well. (6/10)

I like character comedies. I like talkative comedies. I like comedies that take place in standard areas that serve simply as a backdrop allowing for characters to get into intelligent comedic arguments and/or discussions. I like intelligent comedies. "My Cousin Vinny" is smart and talkative; in one of the better scenes, Vincent Gambini (Joe Pesci) and his fiancée Mona Lisa Vito (Marisa Tommie) get into an argument over a dripping faucet. I love this stuff.That's not to say that I don't enjoy other forms of comedy. I respect them when done correctly. But for me, character-driven stories and conversations has always been the strongest example of pure filmmaking; of getting inside the heads of others.Billy (Ralph Macchio) and his buddy Stan are traveling through Wahzoo, Alabama, when they are unjustly picked up for the murder of a local gas station attendant. Thrown into the slammer, their only hope is one man: Vinny (Pesci), an energetic, smart-mouthed little guy who happens to be Billy's cousin and a lawyer. He assures them that he'll get them off the hook, despite the fact that he's never even entered a courtroom before. "How long have you been practicing?" Stan asks. "Almost six weeks," Vinny says.Vinny's brought his fiancée, Mona Lisa Vito (Tommie), to Wahzoo with him. They rent out a room at a local motel and get into heated debates whilst the fate of Vinny's cousin and his friend rest with him. At the first day of trial, Vinny says absolutely nothing to help his case. The prosecution's lawyer (Joe Don Baker) makes Vinny look like a schmuck, quizzing witnesses over important eyewitness accounts. Vinny just sits there.He's not a very good lawyer, as we can tell from the start. And the court judge (Fred Gwynne in his last film role) isn't too enthused with his courtroom manner. But he gets better as time goes on, with the help of his smart fiancée and with the cheering of his cousin. Vinny proves he's a pretty good lawyer by the time everything's over.I didn't enjoy "My Cousin Vinny" as much as I should have. Taking everything into account, it is a very good comedy. It's built with a strong foundation of a witty script; funny characters and clever dialogue, not to mention an overall joyful feel to it. Nevertheless, I wasn't as enthralled on my first viewing of the film as I had hoped I would be. My second viewing, last night, was better.Joe Pesci is perfect as Vinny, a lovable clown who prides himself in the fact that he thinks he knows everything, but most of the time his pride backfires when he finds out he's not quite as clever as he thinks. Marisa Tomei (who won an Oscar for her supporting role) is hilarious as the straight guy (or gal) of the story. Fred Gwynne is great; this was his final appearance on film, as he died soon after filming wrapped.The movie has some very funny cultural comparisons, the most evident one the argument over the meaning of the word "youths," which Vinny pronounces "yutes." There's also a good scene when Vinny and Mona Lisa first arrive in Wahzoo and step out of their car clad in leather and jewelry and general city clothing. "You stick out like a sore thumb around here," he says. "At least I've got cowboy boots." Lisa looks at him and says, "Oh, yeah, you blend."Another fine aspect of this film is how strong the courtroom scenes are. Instead of serving simply as a premise for the film to induce chuckles, it has some very interesting and thoughtful scenes, probably enough to go around for ten courtroom movies. There's a discussion towards the end about cars and their tires that had me wondering how the scriptwriters did such detailed research.In many ways, this movie reminded me of the 1987 comedy "Planes, Trains and Automobiles," which I am always bringing up in my reviews. But somehow they're closely related. I think it's the dialogue. It's like John Hughes himself said: "I always liked character stories best - put two or more people in a room and get them talking." I like those movies, too. I've always liked them. I like when characters get into lengthy, deep debates about trivial things. I love comedic conversations. "My Cousin Vinny" has a lot of 'em. It's a nice distraction from the overblown goofball comedies flooding the market today that lack any sort of cohesion and wit necessary to make a strong comedy. "My Cousin Vinny" has got it all.4/5 stars.John Ulmer

I just watched "My Cousin Vinny" again on HBO. I can not count how many times I have seen it. I know the exact line that is coming and I chuckle every time. The reason I find it so watchable is the sensational performances by all cast members (OK maybe not Machio!). My most vivid memory of the movie was that after seeing the theatrical release and thinking it was hysterical, I rented it while on vacation with my folks. To be honest, I didn't remember the language being so... ah... harsh, and I sat there in shock thinking they would be mortified. Well, after 15 minutes my Mom was howling with every morning wake up, every confrontation with the judge, and we almost lost her when Austin Pendelton started his "stuttering" defense! She loved Marisa Tomei (who didn't?)! I will never forget that night.The movie itself is the classic "fish out of water" tale. Joe Pesci, who I always found annoying in his Mafia roles, is perfect as the New Yorker who will "learn as he goes along". And Marisa Tomei, his long suffering girlfriend, creates a character so coarse, blunt, likable and drop dead gorgeous, I haven't seen her equal since. I am always amazed that people question her Acadamy Award credentials. The fact that comic turns are not often rewarded doesn't mean it wasn't a sensational characterization. And this was also a career capping role for Fred Gwynne. He captures the respectful Southern Gentlemen Judge, struggling to suppress his slow burn, perfectly. So tune in if you haven't seen it, enjoy it again if you have. This is great entertainment, but remember, its rated R for language!!

In one word : HILARIOUS! Joe Pesci is a hoot as a fish out of water attorney trying to save his cousin and his friend on trial for a murder they didn't commit. Marisa is equally hilarious as his fiancee, Mona Lisa Vito (love that name!). Watch and laugh your a** off! "You're gonna shoot a deer!"

reviews.review_title: An above average 'fish out of water' comedy
reviews.content: "My Cousin Vinny" arrived not too long after Joe Pesci's Oscar win for his classic performance in "GoodFellas", where he memorably badgered Ray Liotta's character into explaining just why he thought he was so funny. Well, in this movie he got to show his comedic chops while still staying close to his explosive tough guy image.In the movie, he plays the titular Vinny, an inexperienced New York lawyer summoned to rural Alabama in order to defend a cousin who has been falsely accused of murder. Needless to say, his irreverent attitude does not endear him to the Southern judge, nor does his seeming incompetence inspire his cousin with much confidence. Fortunately, Vinny's long-suffering fiancée Lisa (Marisa Tomei) is determined to lend a hand so that justice prevails in spite of Vinny's lack of refinement.Although Pesci was the star of the movie it was Tomei who ended up practically stealing the show. Nevertheless, her subsequent Oscar win was a surprise to many and I can see why. In my opinion, her later Oscar nominations for "In the Bedroom" and (especially) "The Wrestler" were both more deserving. In any case, in addition to having good chemistry together, Pesci & Tomei also had a stellar cast of character actors supporting them. With the likes of Fred Gwynne, Lane Smith, James Rebhorn & Bruce McGill (among others), the cast is way better than you'd have any right to expect (even considering the questionable casting of ex-Karate Kid Ralph Macchio).Director Jonathan Lynn holds a Law degree from Cambridge, so he was seemingly a good choice for the project. Nevertheless, I was surprised to find that the movie has been praised by lawyers for its authenticity along with its illustration of various legal procedures, strategies & principles. What's odd is that an outwardly light comedy like this actually has a foundation of credibility. Meanwhile, in purely visual terms, although the movie may not be anything particularly special, Lynn still demonstrates more than once his ability to use the camera to produce comedic effects.All in all, "My Cousin Vinny" is a pretty good light comedy. Joe Pesci seems a bit out of place here but, then again, that's kind of the point. In any case, the story's entertaining and the cast in general is well above average. I'd say that it's definitely worth a look, even if it doesn't quite measure up to the all-time classics of the genre.
A film with a different story from the usual judicial comedies, with a little laughs and with a great Joe Pesci who confirms himself as an actor from all film genres.

reviews.review_title: Feel-Good Comedy that Breaks All the Rules
reviews.content: "My Cousin Vinny" isn't the great court room drama because it's filled with things that are simply against the rules of court, but since the film is told in such tongue-and-check fashion, it simply adds to the great on-screen chemistry of the actors involved and themes of the film. People may argue that's its contrived, ridiculous, and all that garbage, but this film isn't to be taken seriously. It's a comedy. It's a feel-good-story of believing in someone, and it is incredibly effective. "My Cousin Vinny" delivers a ton of laughs, some great acting from Pesci, Tomei, and Fred Gwynne. Joe Pesci and Marisa Tomei have a ton of fun with this role and really do a great job acting off one another. We become so invested in this story and so invested with their determination that we're sucked into these characters. A smile is brought to your face just listening to them talk. The court room scenes are dynamite. "My Cousin Vinny" is a classic feel- good comedy that's enjoyable from start to finish.

i have actually LOST COUNT as to HOW MANY TIMES i've seen this movie! for me, it gets BETTER EACH TIME I WATCH IT! we have cable (we're SOOOOO etc... spoiled! LOL!) and each time i 'channel surf' and it's on, i sit and watch it! PLUS, we have it on DVD too! i am from brooklyn, ny and I KNOW people who actually "TAWK" that way! i do, but i don't have THAT heavy a brooklyn accent 'cause i lived out of state for a few years. ( i learned how to 'tawk' properly... LOL!) anyway, the movie is great! very well written, very detailed characters, perfect actors for the roles! i LOVE how you can see vinny 'growing' as a lawyer each time he's in the courtroom! it's wonderful! joe pesci is wonderful as vinny! i CANNOT see ANYONE else in those roles! no way! honestly, each time i watch it, i find NEW things! very funny movie too! joe pesci & marisa tomei have great chemistry too! i LOVE them all!

reviews.review_title: No Kidding,The Best Comedy after "Meet The Parents"
reviews.content: Can't believe it!i never noticed this movie before.Yesterday,one of the channel television in my country was turning on this movie.And you know what,i can't stopped my laugh and my tears which it came on and on..again and again...until the "end credit" showed up! Without a doubt,This is the Greatest and Magnificent hilarious-comedy of all time.I never saw the Great Comedy as funny as "Meet the Parents" until i found this one as the "Next Brilliant Comedy" after all.This movie was giving us everything:Genius Directing,Magnificent Casting and Smart-Funny Plot.For Cast,Marisa Tomei truly deserved get the Oscar for her role as Lisa,Vincent's Bambini fiancé.Aside her,pesci was giving his Top-Notch performance as Genuine Comedian in Hollywood Cinema.Ralph Macchio still didn't lose his Charms and Brilliant Acting as like as his leading role in Best Martial-Art Drama "Karate Kid trilogy".GOD..Everybody who loves very much with comedy,Needs to see this one!You won't regret it!I guarantee 100%! Wants to buy it in DVD.Grade:10 from 10

reviews.review_title: Wish Cousin Vinny was my eternity
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny is about 2 guys on a road trips through the south. they got caught by the police thinking they were responsible for a crime they didn't even committed.Held in jail in the state of Alabama the duo needs an eternity to get themselves off their trail.luckily one of them has a cousin who's a lawyer.Vinny is a third rate lawyer from New York. And the only one who can help our duo out of their mess. The only trouble is he hasn't work any actual trail before and has no experience in winning a trail.But when he studies more about law and order and having more faith in himself he'll be able to help our duo out of trail.It's a very cool movie. Plenty of laughs and jokes. Joe Pesci is excellent with his role too. It's worth seeing if you like Joe Pesci.

Well, this captures Georgia all right. Small-town Georgia, with its loblolly and slash pine forests and red clay earth, and its baked-brick buildings, and hard-charging justice system. The South in many ways is one of the most laid-back areas of the country; everybody's friendly-like, elderly neighbors visit newcomers and bring them home-made pies. But, don't laugh, it reminds me a bit of Inuit life. People can get away with quite a lot in a traditional Eskimo community as long as they generally stick to the norms. When they don't, they get killed. Not shunned, not fined, not chastized, not remonstrated with, not exiled -- killed. "My Cousin Vinny" is a movie that I find myself enjoying each time I watch it, although the story is simple enough and could easily be done poorly. Fortunately, given that the escapade depicted isn't by its nature hilarious, the picture is rather smoothly done, with advantage taken of every opporunity for humor. The underlying drama wears thin after the first viewing, but it's still filled with laughs. Joe Pesci can't help his presence seeming ridiculous, even in his heavy roles for Scorcesi. He simply SOUNDS funny. Marisa Tomei is slender and sweetly appealing. Her relationship with Pesci is a nice mixture of love, frustration, and resignation. She's smarter than he is, as well as much better looking. Fred Gwynn and Lane Smith are the local authority figures, judge and prosecutor respectively. But no one could accuse them of playing Southern stereotypes. The Judge is sharp, a Yale graduate and chess player, and allows no tomfoolery in his courtroom, although Pesci provides plenty of it. Smith, playing a Southern lawyer for the one-hundredth-and-fortieth time, is at least as good as he's ever been. Here, he's affable and full of principle, going out of his way to help Pesci and Mona Lisa find a quiet place to live. His roller coaster of an accent is a delight to listen to. And, like the others, he has some good lines. "Verdict," he tells the jury in his summation, "it means the truth. Comes down to us from our lil IL' ancestors in Europe," and the director gives us a brief shot of an African-American woman in the jury box listening intently. Ralph Macchio's part is rather small, which doesn't detract at all from the movie. He has one good moment. Interrogated by a sheriff, he thinks he's being arrested for stealing a can of tuna fish and knows nothing of the murder he's thought to have committed. He admits to the sheriff that, yes, in fact he stole the tuna. The sheriff says, "Was that before or after you shot the clerk?" There are about two exquisite seconds while Macchio continues staring straight ahead as this query sinks into his understanding, then he looks up as if doubting his senses, and says, "I shot the clerk?", which the sheriff immediately grasps as a straightforward confession.If you get a chance to see this, you might as well do so. I hope you can get the unexpurgated version so you can pick up on one of the films funniest exchanges after Pesci has repeatedly made a fool of himself in the courtroom. "Counselor," says the judge, "I'm holding you in contempt." And Pesci mutters under his breath as he sits down, "What the f*** else is new?"Fred Gwynn's jaw drops and his expression of incomprehension has me smiling just thinking about it. It isn't a masterpiece of comedy, but it's a pleasant way to get through a few hours.

reviews.review_title: Best Comedy I have Ever Seen
reviews.content: I never expected that I'd like this movie so much. The film centers on a comedic lawyer and his loudmouth gorgeous wife. His mission is to set free two kids who injust accused for murder (one of the kids is his cousin). He always screw things up. His wife tries to help him, but he always sents her off, until he realise he need her help. The movie gave Marisa Tomei an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress. She made the performance of her lifetime alongside Joe Pesci who was amazing as well. The movie wouldn't be so good if it wasn't for these actors. There are great comedic scenes that will cheer you up. The final act of the film is truly unforgetable and was the one that gave Marisa her Oscar, an Oscar she fully deserved. The movie is acclaimed by both critics and public. In my opinion it deserves a place in IMDb's Top 250 movies.

This movie is one of the best movies that i have ever seen. I have watched it at least 20 times and its always funny.Merisa tomei is great in her role. Joe has never been better. This is a great movie.The beginning sets up for a great ending and everything in between is a treat.

The actors are great in their parts and convincing as a couple. The movie is your standard fish-out-of water story.  But Pesci and Tomei are so good that you forget the plot is so weak and underdeveloped.

reviews.review_title: Chemistry makes this movie a win
reviews.content: Best part of this movie is the chemistry between Vinny and Lisa. Everything else is hit or miss.

reviews.review_title: A thinly disguised anti-death penalty court-room drama.
reviews.content: Is this supposed to be a comedy? There was very little to smile at, let alone to laugh out loud to. This is merely a political Hollywood drama posing as a comedy; yet another attempt to sway all us "vile, wretched, pro-death penalty souls" into believing that practically every person accused of a major crime is innocent, while the real killer/rapist/whatever is hiding somewhere, safe and happy. All the humanity! All the conspiracy! Apart from its blatant liberal leanings, this movie has another purpose, albeit a less conscious i.e. intentional/relevant one: to yet again mock the people from the South of the States, portraying them as dumb and evil hicks. After all, the New York characters are all likable - even smart - whereas MCV's townsfolk are all either borderline morons or corrupt/immoral. But of course: as we all know, New York nearly always votes Left/Democrat - plus, it's the second-largest center of the film industry in the world - so OBVIOUSLY New Yorkers must be superior to those damn Southerners with their retarded twang and lack of morality and common-sense. What a load of b...Pesci is quite solid playing an unreal character. Tomei tries hard with HER unreal character, but fails because the part was written in such a stereotypical fashion that it was impossible even for much better actresses than her to make that role seem as if it had any basis in reality. She is a caricature, not a character, hence she is neither funny for the supposed humorous bits, nor believable for the dramatic bits. She reminds of Lesley-Anne Warren's ditzy character in "Victor/Victoria", but without being nearly as funny or likable as her; plus, that was an actual comedy, not a political-statement movie. Tomei talks like a typical dumb NY harlot, and yet her vocabulary shames even those absurdly eloquent young characters from "Dawson's Creek". You can't have your cake and eat it too: have a character that behaves like an utter moron, and yet imply that there is some fantastic unrealized intellectual potential lurking behind the extremely silly exterior. It wouldn't even work in a REAL comedy (which this isn't at all), let alone in a comedy drama with some quite serious social pretensions/ambitions.To make things worse, there are long court scenes which, as we all know, the American audiences adore so much. The fact that most Tinseltown court-room movies don't have an iota of realism in them doesn't seem to bother anyone - i.e. people aren't even aware of this obvious, simple fact. Just stuff your face with popcorn and whatever you do, don't think, please...So why did Tomei get an Oscar? Well, obviously, this is a political film - Leftist, as always - and Hollywood likes to reward its sheep-like obedient film-makers in propagating its way of life and thinking.If you want to make it in Hollywood, all you need to do is shout how liberal you are, for as long as your throat can bear it. Success is guaranteed...Please punish me hard, very HARD, by clicking "no" below. That'll teach me...

reviews.review_title: The funniest American courtroom drama ever !
reviews.content: I give this movie a 9 because I've watched this movie a record 32 times (if not more in bits and pieces) and still manage to fall off the chair laughing through most parts of the movie.I watched it first on a VCD and later found a featured DVD a few years later for a few extra quid. I would still pay for any material about this movie that I can lay my hands on.The confusion at the cell with Stan, the sleepless nights and their many reasons, the break-in break-off relationship with Mona, the intimidating judge 'who's just aching to throw Vinny in jail', and the twisted excitement in the end; all give 'My cousin Vinny' everything a serious comedy needs. It's quite surprising that Joe Pesci has never been set in the lead role in a comedy till date. The reel-life chemistry between Marrisa Tomei and Joe Pesci has been quite appealing and could never be any better or even the same if any of the actors were played by anybody else.The movie, however failed to get the recognition it deserves, but I'm glad I watched this movie soon after its release.I recommended this highly for anyone who visits this page and for those trying to make a decision to watch.

Man, Joe Pesci never disappoints. A courtroom comedy classic. I originally watched this for my Law 12 class but loved it so much that I watched it again. Have you holding on to your stomach as you laugh so much it hurts. Personally I could watch it multiple times and not get bored. It's a light hearted movie to watch after heartbreaking movies to ease off. The supporting characters really add a lot to the movie and make everything ten times funnier. I wanna thank my law teacher for introducing this movie to me, because life is definitely better with it.My favorite quote:
{Opening statement} 'everything that guy just said is bullshit... thank you.'

reviews.review_title: Joe Pesci can be funny. Marisa Tomei can...win an Oscar?
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny is an OK comedy. Nothing spectacular but it's reasonably amusing and all in all pretty fun. It's the kind of movie which comes along, provides a few chuckles, and then disappears, destined to be more or less forgotten. But this particular movie will always be remembered because of one of the great Academy Awards upsets of all time. Marisa Tomei took home the Oscar for best supporting actress and to this day it still seems a little hard to believe. That's not a knock on Tomei, her performance is indeed very good. But it's not the type of role, and certainly not the type of movie, which generally attracts Oscar votes. The fact Tomei even scored a nomination seems surprising. That she actually won boggles the mind.While Tomei got the glittering golden statue it is Joe Pesci who has the central role in the movie. Here Pesci gets a chance to show he's not just the tough guy you know from Goodfellas. He's funny. Pesci plays Vincent 'Vinny' Gambini in what will prove to be one of those classic fish out of water tales. His young cousin and a friend were traveling through rural Alabama and they have rather unfortunately found themselves charged with a murder they did not commit. The evidence against them appears strong and the two youths seem destined for the electric chair. Who will defend them? Enter Vinny Gambini. OK, so he's just passed the bar after six attempts and he's never actually tried a case and this stereotypical New Yorker is completely out of his element in the Deep South...but I'm sure he'll do a bang-up job right?There are some pretty good laughs as we see Vinny try to build a defense despite all the obstacles in his way. Of course no obstacle being greater than the fact that he appears to have no idea what he's doing. Along for the ride is Vinny's girlfriend, Mona Lisa Vito. No, really. You couldn't make that name up. This of course is Tomei's role and she does quite well with it. The verbal salvos being lobbed back and forth between her and Pesci really work. There's certainly nothing about her performance that screams out "Oscar" but that would be the end result. Giving just as good of a supporting performance as Tomei is Fred Gwynne, playing a judge who will find himself often butting heads with Vinny. Other than that there's not much. Playing the two youths on trial Ralph Macchio and Mitchell Whitfield don't have much of anything to do after the film's first few minutes. They're just sitting at the defense table watching Pesci do his thing. Pesci has to carry the movie and he proves up to the task. It's a mostly entertaining story, there's some snappy dialogue and good comedic bits sprinkled throughout. But at times the movie does struggle to maintain momentum. You get the sense 15-20 minutes could easily have been trimmed off the two hour running time to produce a much tighter, more focused story. In the end it's no comedy classic but it is amusing enough.

This is a very enjoyable movie. Just sit back and enjoy Marisa Tomei and Joe Pesci do their thing. They are two brilliant actors who manage to keep up the momentum in the movie without losing their humoristic and personal style.

If this film was rated nine out of ten on its original release it's STILL an eight minimum all these years later, it's just a case of EVERYTHING, story, setting, and performances coming together and really complementing each other. It could of course be argued that to a certain extent it was manipulative; for one thing it's set in Alabama and seasoned film buffs know that in certain situations the Deep South sends itself up without really trying. Next you have the culture shock, sophisticated (by definition) Noo Yawkers, yet naïve with it when adrift in the boonies. Throw in an uncouth lawyer who hasn't actually tried a murder case and pit him against a courtly judge of the old school and what's not to like. Joe Pesci and Marisa Tomei are beyond praise and it's criminal that no one ever exploited their outstanding talents subsequently. Fred Gywnne would have walked away with the movie if he hadn't come up against Tomei and Pesci. Brilliant.
I love this film! So funny, was one of the reasons I became a solicitor (Pitt reality isn't as funny) proper giggle

reviews.review_title: The way a comedy should be
reviews.content: This is probably one of the best comedies ever written. You could rewatch 100 times and still laugh. It is timeless. The clash of cultures is perfectly done and the way the actors play off of eachother is perfect.

reviews.review_title: A character driven comedy excellently played
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny could be a mess in the wrong hands. Thanks to Joe Pesci, Marisa Tomei, Fred Gwynne and the other main cast members, and to Jonathan Lynn, the film's director, it succeeds and is quite entertaining.Much has been said in a non-complimentary fashionabout several of the acting efforts in the film, but it's the acting that elevates the film from run of the mill ho-hum fare to one which keeps you laughing on repeat viewings.Recently, I watched the film on DVD and listened to Jonathan Lynn's audio commentary. I found his anecdotes to be charming, insightful and informative. Getting inside the mind of the director and reasons he used particular shots and dialog was fascinating and engaging, and I think listening to someone, other than one of the performers, is also educational.I would recommend the film to anyone who wants some light entertainment that really isn't mindless, but infused with good performances and a well done film.

Despite the amazing acting by Marisa Tomei who gave to her an Oscar in a supporting role, the main attraction without doubt is around La Guardia and The judge Chamberlain Haller, they are quite opposite each other, actually they live in different worlds, the chemistry between both is outrageous hilarious, since the beginning, they are a case apart, which steals the whole movie, the funniest moments are polarized by their stunning acting!! Maybe the best performance of Joe Pesci in your entire career including Goodfellas!!Resume:First watch: 1994 / How many: 4 / Source: DVD / Rating: 8

reviews.review_title: Pesci's fish out of water story. He actually survives.
reviews.content: Really good comedy that relies on mostly intelligent observation rather than gross-out humour.The story is a bit far-fetched but we somehow buy it because of the execution of the law scenes. Joe Pesci may not look anything like a lawyer but as Ralph Macchio's character Bill states: "He loves to argue".Several scenes are priceless. Take the first scene with such signs as "Free horse manure". Is this south bashing? Absolutely! But it does give you a laugh.Then there is the scene in prison between Mitchell Whitfield and Pesci. "You're getting' f..... either way!" And you can't get enough of all that southern charm that just oozes out of the prosecutor, Lane Smith.The bit with the stuttering public defender is a bit sick but I guess the director needed a positive argument for Joe Pesci's character to be the more competent of the two. Austin Pendleton does it well too despite objections from his part.And yes. One of the few comedies that was rewarded with an Oscar to an actor, the gorgeous Marisa Tomei (you can understand why George Costanza was so obsessed with her). Many jokes has been made at her expense and that only fuels the speculation about her being the rightful winner that year. In my mind it couldn't have been a goof. She absolutely nails the character and does it without the stereotyping in which these characters are usually played.Joe Pesci's career have had more downs than ups. Remember the tremendously awful "The Super" but here he gave us a really compelling character. He is smug, selfish and yes a bit of a tool but he plays it with such tongue-in-cheek that you can't help loving the guy.

reviews.review_title: Very entertaining, but was hoping for more laughs.
reviews.content: MY COUSIN VINNYI have been wanting to see this film for many years, but never really got round to it.It was OK, but not as good as I was expecting.The film is about 2 lads who go to a gas station whilst on a road trip, they leave buying a lot of items, but realise in the car that they have a tin of tuna that they didn't pay for. When the police pull them over and arrest them, they think they have been booked for theft... but they are booked for murder. They are broke and have no-one to defend them... except Cousin Vinny. It is then comedy from there.The film is funny in places, but not really laugh out loud funny. It was amusing and fun to watch, but I didn't laugh out loud at many points.The film stars Joe Pesci as cousin Vinny. I like Joe. He has made a lot of good movies, but this is not his best. He also looked like he had his face pinned back. His eyes looked stretched back. I wonder if he had surgery or something? Joe was good in this film though... his character was the funny character in the film. I loved his attitude and the language he uses.Other cast members were Ralph Macchio, Marisa Tomei, Mitchell Whitfield & Fred Gwynne.They all did well. The acting wasn't brilliant, but it is a comedy, so the way they played it was really good.A lot of the film is set in a court room which can be boring sometimes, but not really here. Joe carries the film through. He is brilliant at keeping you entertained and that is what he does here.I will give this film 6 out of 10.I did like it, but I was expecting more.For more of my reviews, please like my Facebook page:https://www.facebook.com/pages/Ordinary-Person-Movie- Reviews/456572047728204?ref=hl

reviews.review_title: Good funny comedy with wit and intelligence. A good showcase of the north and south culture wars!
reviews.content: I must say 1992's "My Cousin Vinny" is a wonderful film the acting, and plot along with the wit and funny moments combined with a culture clash make for a good enjoyable film. Going away from this film you take away and appreciate the cultural differences of the north and south. Being raised a southern I knew what to expect, and visiting up north I saw as you see with these Yankee folks their way of life is different.Two laid back and wild out to seek adventure New York college students are taking a sight seeing tour thru the deep south. And while in Alabama, they are arrested and accused of murder! One of the boys(Ralph Macchio)has a family friend who's just finally became a lawyer after six times of taking the bar! That's Vincent Gambini(well done by Joe Pesci)a Brooklyn guy who's a former auto repair guy, and guess what this is his first court case! So Vinny arrives in Alabama with his hot and sexy strong spoken smart girlfriend Mona(in Marisa Tomei's best role). And this is the start of big lessons in law and most of all southern culture! Thru it all with wit and common sense intelligence rightful justice is served. Most rewarding is the lessons of culture shock for Vinny and the boys, it's so comical hearing the southern accents, and it was funny seeing Vinny ask southerns what are grits! Great supporting work from Tomei a nice eye candy treat. As this was one comedy to laugh at while appreciating the cultural differences.

A lawyer who lies more than Pinocchio is elected to help two guys who've been mistakenly accused for murderer. The outcome is visible: lots of troubles. Whilst Ralph Macchio's character could have contracted a decent lawyer, he prefers to contract his "Cousin Vinny" because "he is family". Obviously, this counselor is worse than anyone else would be in this profession. He doesn't understand what the Judge says and builds a strange relationship with him. Marisa Tomei's character (Vinny's wife) is as annoying as it could be, but she has an oddly charisma which made me like her.The first hour of the film had some funny jokes involving irony and naivety, but the other hour forgot it was a comedy film. Instead of that, the writers insisted in building a silly story with a bizarre lawyer. The movie is entertaining and interesting once you realize this is just a low-budget film with an original situation, but won't be much real or believable.

I watched My Cousin Vinny for the first time about 12 years after release. I decided to check it out again all these years later and it still mostly holds up. It's an enjoyable movie, pretty funny, and surprisingly investing.I'm guessing a lot of the courtroom stuff isn't very plausible but I didn't mind. The premise is intriguing and it's set up well. There are a bunch of good characters and memorable performances.I don't think this is something I'll keep going back to, but I'm glad I watched it again. It's an easy watch for a boring day and a good throwback to the movies of my "yoot." (2 viewings, 10/15/2022)

reviews.review_title: Didn't know Pesci could be so funny
reviews.content: The title, I think, suggests a less than memorable film. But dont let it mislead you. This is an original take on "big city goes to the country (or vice versa) theme. Turns out to be an funny and entertaining movie. Vinny's (Pesci) sarcastic attitude throughout the movie is comical. And Tomei is EXCELLENT supporting role! (not to mention her other qualities).

reviews.review_title: Realistic Portrayal of the South Wins
reviews.content: While this is a movie about a murder trial of two wrongly accused New York youths, it proves to be a taughtly written and acted story (with a comedic edge) about people.It is so wonderfully refreshing that the Southerners are not portrayed as morons. One character "J.T.", played by Chris Ellis, is only a poolroom bully - and those exist everywhere in every culture.The entire cast is wonderful to watch. Excellent movies start with excellent casting.Fred Gwynn, who plays "Judge Chamberlain Haller," is incredibly wonderful to watch. I always knew that his acting ability was stellar, above and beyond any of Hollywood's finest. And this movie proves it. The subtley of his looks toward Joe Pesci's character, and his other gestures are gems that all aspiring actors should *study*.Mitchell Whitfield as "Stan Rothenstein," Lane Smith as "D.A. Jim Trotter, III," and Bruce McGill as "Sheriff Dean Farley" were true to their characters to the utmost. As I said, an excellent movie starts with an excellent cast.Great movie, great entertainment, great writing, great direction, and great acting - see it as often as it airs. (Closing song is a real toe-taper.) 9/10-Zafoid

reviews.review_title: An entertaining way to learn about legal proceedings
reviews.content: When it comes to courtroom movies, there aren't many more entertaining than My Cousin Vinny. Joe Pesci and Marisa Tomei carry most of this film on their shoulders, but Fred Gwynne is a delight to watch in his final performance, as well. I learned a lot of what I know about legal proceedings from My Cousin Vinny, it's very well written, and I find myself chuckling every time I watch it.

reviews.review_title: Can a movie be one of the funniest and have an enjoyable story?
reviews.content: I have watched this a few times so I will base it on this first time I ever saw it. One of the best comedies I ever saw, and for a comedy it was surely very interesting with an outstanding hilarious story. A true masterpiece with all actors giving their life time performances. If I was asked what could be done to make this movie better, I would say absolutely nothing it's already excellent. It always says a lot for a movie when you wish it could have been longer. Don't expect it to be anything like the comedy in The Naked Gun, although an outstanding comedy also, not so much the slap stick type comedy, as it is a story with constant funny incidences. This is a great must see movie.

reviews.review_title: What Is So Good About This Movie?
reviews.content: There are load of positive review about this movie and some of them even make a fan club, I really don't get it why this movie is so great to them. Tell the truth IMHO this is one very average movie.The story about Vinny, a phony lawyer trying to save his innocent cousin and his friend from the first-degree murder charge.It took two times for me to actually enjoy the movie. The acting was good but not the Oscar material and that left me highly doubted how did Marisa Tomei could even ran into the nominee (before having won it).The movie is okay but it is not that good as what people have been saying.Recommendation: Watch It Once Or Twice Rating: 6/10 (Grade: C+)

"My Cousin Vinny" is a Comedy - Crime movie in which we watch two young men getting in trouble during a misunderstanding. They accused of murder and the cousin of one of them who is lawyer takes action in order to save them.I liked this movie because it had an interesting plot and it was simply hilarious at many points. In addition to this, the interpretation of Joe Pesci who played as Vinny Gambini was simply the best and he was very funny in most of the time. Both interpretations of Ralph Macchio who played as Bill Gambini and Mitchell Whitfield who played as Stan Rothenstein were good and along with the beautiful Marisa Tomei who played as Mona Lisa Vito had this excellent result. Lastly, I have to say that I strongly recommend everyone to watch this movie because you are going to have a great time watching it and you will laugh a lot.

A really well-casted, funny but not trying too hard to be funny comedy which I think puts Pesci in his best type of role that doesn't involve a pen. The pacing is good, never really bogging down as some movies do (though that's my own pet peeve and might not be as important to others) which is important for this kind of story that has a serious courtroom thing done for laughs.The best part, though? Marisa Tomei in those clothes with that accent. I would watch a two hour vacuum commercial if she was in it playing this character. Might buy two.

reviews.review_title: Joe Pesci Brings a Lot of Life in to a very Simple Character,
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny is a good movie with a well developed storyline and a great comedic cast.Its mostly very funny,I think there are many scenes that miss,but the scenes that are funny are hilarious,the scenes that are cringe comedy are definitely the ones that work the best in this movie.Joe Pesci does a great job as Vinny Gambini,the character was very basic for a comedy film and easily could have been played by any random comedy actor,but getting someone as talented as Pesci to play this character brings much more life in to the Vinny and makes him so much likable.Marisa Tomei also does a fantastic job in this movie,her character was funny,clever and very independent,I honestly don't think she deserved an Academy Award for this movie but her performance was certainly the movies best.I don't My Cousin Vinny is laugh out loud from start to finish,but the scenes that are funny are very funny,and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a good comedy.When two New Yorkers are accused of murder in rural Alabams,one of their cousins,an inexperienced,loudmouth lawyer not accustomed to Southern rules,comes in to defend them.

reviews.review_title: A court-room comedy in which Joe Pesci tries to save the lives of two "yutes".
reviews.content: Vinny (Joe Pesci) tries to save the lives of two guys who get caught up in a murder deep in the heart of Alabama.  Ralph Macchio and Mitchell Whitfield are on their way to college when they get arrested for the murder of a convenience store worker.  Vinny and his girlfriend (Marisa Tomei) try to work their New York antics on the court system in Alabama.  The Judge (Fred Gywnne) doesn't put up with Vinny's tactics and Vinny gets to spend many "happy" nights in jail.  This is Vinny's first case ever and the movie flows along very cleverly while Vinny tries all the tricks of the trade to get the two "yutes" from being electricuted.  This movie is very funny and will keep you laughing the whole way through. It will defintely make you think about who you choose as a lawyer the next time your in trouble with the law.

2 boys accidentally steal a tin of tuna from a gas station in Alabama but are arrested for murder. They ask their recently accredited, inexperienced but street savvy cousin Vinny (Pesci) to be their lawyer. He in turn is accompanied by his equally street smart fiancée (Tomei).Very witty and affectionate comedy has both the leads in fine form. Best though is director Lynn's handling of everything and Launer's script particularly the hilarious first exchange and incredible misunderstanding in the jail.

This comedy has it all. The thing I like about this movie is that Vinny (Joe Pesci) gets caught up with a lot of other problems than just this trial, which is about to put 2 innocent guys in the "chair" because of a murder they didn't do. Vinny can't get any sleep at night because there is ALWAYS some annoying sound that wakes him up and he has to win 200$ back in a fight against one big guy who's just looking for a fight. And all this is so funny! I really recommend it!!

This is one of those rare, nearly flawless films.  Pesci plays a perfect role as Vincent Gambini.  And Marisa Tomei?  Whoa! She is HOT in this film. None of her characters in her other films, even comes close to Mona Lisa Vito!  She is gorgeous, and HOT!  And you've got to love her accent!

This is a great comedy with all the right ingredients! A very funny plot, great acting performances. I fell in love with Marisa Tomei as Mona Lisa Vito in this movie. Brooklyn accent has never been this sexy! And Joe Pesci is as brilliant as ever. And there is a lot of funny details and they work!

Joe Pesci, Marisa Tomei, Ralph Macchio, Mitchell Whitfield and Fred Gwynne star in this 1992 comedy. This begins with 2 college pals, Bill (Macchio) and Stan (Whitfield) traveling through Alabama and stop for groceries. Soon, they're arrested and on trial for murdering the clerk. Bill seeks help from his cousin, Vinny (Pesci) who's been studying Law, but has little experience to clear their names. Tomei (Spider-Man: Homecoming) plays Vinny's fiancée, Lisa and the late, Gwynne (The Munsters) plays Judge, Chamberlain Haller. Pesci is funny as usual, he and Tomei are great in this and have good chemistry. I recommend this good 90's comedy.

reviews.review_title: One of My Family Favorites from Childhood That Never Gets Old
reviews.content: Even Andre Bazin and Jean-Luc Godard surely had films they found difficulty watching objectively. We all are attached to at least one certain movie that resonates with our childhoods, holidays, families and different circles of friends. My Cousin Vinny is at least one film that I watch in pure vegetation no matter how exorbitant my film snobbery gets over the years. I know a guy who seems to watch nothing but gangster and samurai movies, and tends to mingle with similar guys, but will always have a place in his heart for Bob Clark's A Christmas Story, just like so many others who cannot watch it without all the signifying perspective of all those Thanksgivings and Christmases. I cannot watch My Cousin Vinny without thinking of my parents, how we all love it when Joe Pesci refers to his defendants as "yutes," much to the bafflement of a courtroom full of small town Southerners who may have never before heard a Brooklyn accent, how Marisa Tomei's Oscar-winning scene on the bench as an expert witness automobile aficionado never seems to get old to us.What does change over time is my view of Joe Pesci's performance. It doesn't weaken. Rather, it carries different associations now than it did when I was younger, before he had much such a huge impact on me playing Tommy in GoodFellas and Nicky in Casino. I had only known him as a relative comic actor playing the pushover in the Lethal Weapon series, a handful of other films that I doubt I could revisit with an eye impartial to my memories of being obsessed with them in grade school. I'd also seen Raging Bull when I was quite young, and it had a definite impact on me as well, and I got to see My Cousin Vinny in a much darker, much more dejected ambiance. Now, I enjoy Pesci's Vinny Gambini for a different reason, how it's a complement to Pesci's work with Scorsese in terms of the background of the actor's associations as we see him here.There has been lots of dispute over the years as to whether or not Marisa Tomei deserved the Oscar for Best Supporting Actress for her work here. It is certainly an unlikely film to garner any Oscars, an unlikely role as well. There have been many actresses similar to her in presence like Gloria Grahame, who did powerhouse work before the Academy finally acknowledged her with an Oscar for The Bad and the Beautiful, in which she has ten minutes of screen time at best and plays a role far from the ballpark of central characters. Marisa's career, however, seems to have worked in reverse. I think that here, as Mona Lisa Vito, she was acknowledged because she, having merely appeared on A Different World and a sparse amount of bit parts, stuns us not only with her staggering physical beauty but with her ability to steal each and every frame in which she appears, even from Pesci, the lead, who had recently won the same award she was to win, and essentially for stealing every scene of GoodFellas, a film with a powerful cast. This is all theoretical, and as I said, it's difficult for me to be objective with this movie.Pesci's lead is in part a typecast, as an Italian-American Brooklynite who thinks a black knit shirt with a gold chain necklace under a black leather jacket is proper courtroom apparel. He might be right if he were a defendant in the Bronx, but the movie takes place in Alabama, and he's the defense attorney for his Italian-American Brooklynite cousin Ralph Macchio, and his Jewish friend Mitchell Whitfield, two innocent college students on their way to school, suddenly having found themselves charged with the murder of a convenience store clerk. The circumstantial evidence looks ruinous, but the worst thing they have going against them is Pesci's all-around absence of legal familiarity.Even though this classic fish-out-of-water story is set in the South and has an early shot of a sign that says "Free Horse Manure," this is not really a hick bash. The judge, played by Fred Gwynne, Mr. Munster himself, prosecutor Lane Smith, Perry White to Dean Cain's Superman and the arresting officer Bruce McGill, D-Day to Belushi's Blutarski, are normal Southern men who aren't trying to hastily sandbag anybody by means of false charges and insufficient evidence, but after gunshots were heard, three different witnesses made a positive identification of the two suspects, fleeing the store in a conspicuous late-1960s Buick convertible. (Cue Marisa.)The movie stores most of its best laughs for the extended climactic courtroom sequence, in which one witness after another forges together the prosecution case, and the guiltless youngsters look decidedly bound for the electric chair. Gwynne's surly functioning in his scenes scenes is outstanding. The defendants are for all intents and purposes a foil. Macchio and Whitfield sit at the defense table and look scared, and that's essentially that. Pesci and Tomei, on the other hand, have an ironic relationship that I liked. Neither one is played as a lunkhead, or a contrast to the other. They're very clever, in their own ways that the by-the- book Southern court isn't used to, but in the middle of a legal undertaking for which they are totally unschooled. Basically, it's a great culture clash movie, not only in the courtroom scenes but in Vinny and Mona's struggle to get any sleep or find a suit or get breakfast or duke it out with a classic barroom redneck for the money he owes them. And I think that's probably it's biggest charm.

reviews.review_title: I consider the movie a classic, hilarious. Blu-ray remaster room for improvement.
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny is hilarious, bordering on classic. It simply never gets old, and the style of comedy is as funny now as when it was filmed (dare I say even funnier as we look back?). All actors in the movie do a fantastic job and the budget was good enough that you never see any areas where they could have improved it. I watch it around once a year, perhaps a little less. My wife doesn't like watching a lot of movies over and over, she's good with My Cousin Vinny. Real comedies like this one are disappearing, I'll always talk about this film when there is conversation about the true greats.From the technical standpoint, I have to report the blu-ray is a little disappointing. (I recently wrote a review on the movie "Big" which will look similar to this one). They never really spent a lot of time on the blu-ray re-master. It wasn't a massive improvement over the DVD, but enough that I'm happy with the purchase. Dynamic range wasn't improved much, nor was the almost foggy look in some scenes. There seems to be a lot of digital noise in some scenes also, but not as bad as some blu-ray re-masters. Sharpness is improved a lot (in most scenes buy many are still very soft) and oddly sound has improved a lot in terms of surround effect. All in all, definitely a winner - especially if you don't yet have the DVD.

A New Yawk lawyer(Pesci) goes to a deep south courtroom for his first case.  This is Pesci's character from "Goodfellas" becomes lawyer in a comedy. He's great. Marisa Tomei is excellent as his girl(won Oscar for this one), she's one of the most beautiful women in movies today. Ralph Macchio is okay as the young cousin who is wrongly arrested for murder, although his buddy, Rothstein, is funny. Herman Munster(Fred Gwynne) is excellent as the judge. Pesci, Gwynne and Tomei couldn't be better cast for these roles and mesh together perfectly. The comic timing is excellent.
You wanna laugh? Watch it. If you enjoy and understand New Yawk accents, you'll appreciate "My Cousin Vinny".

reviews.review_title: one heck of a comic gem
reviews.content: Great performances abound in this terrific comedy as Joe Pesci tries to free his nephews from an Alabama prison. Problems:    a)this is Pesci's first case, as he has just passed his bar exam on the sixth try, b)his leather jacket and Manhattan attitudes clash horribly with the southern town and the conservative judge, and    c)all the cirmcumstantial evidence points to the nephews. Other than that, things get off to a great start!Marissa Tomei deserved her Oscar for this film. I think you'd like this!*** out of ****

I have such fond memories of this movie. Sitting around and watching it with my grandfather when I was a kid, but it has been over a decade since I watched it. Found it streaming, on Hulu I believe, and I couldn't help but turn it on and see if it held up or if it had just been built up in my head with pure nostalgia.Nope, still really like this movie. It's still hilarious to me, well acted, clever and just a lot of fun. Everyone in this is delightful. It's not perfect but I still really enjoy it. Still not sure Tomei have an Oscar-worthy performance but she is good and wonderfully charming.I think this is absolutely worth visiting, whether you've never seen it or haven't in a long time. Fortunately, with it streaming right now, watching this is easier than ever.

Spoilers I have watched this movie almost every time it is played on TV. It is one of my favorites. It is funny at times, but not quirky or silly. In the end, the movie gathers good momentum toward a good climax that makes one feel like cheering. If one listens to the inspirational climax without watching the screen, at that point you still feel like cheering.There are some very minor plot flaws, that one has to get past to enjoy the ending, but they are hardly noticeable and are not worth pointing out.The movie shows two guys Bill Gambini and Stan enrolled in UCLA who happened to be an Alabama store just prior to the store clerk being shot. They are arrested and questioned and they believe they were arrested for shoplifiting a can of tuna and confess to shoplifting, but are arreingned for murder of the shop clerk. Bill Gambini enlists the services of his cousin Vinny, who has passed the Bar and wants to be a lawyer. Vinny knows nothing about trial law and is therefore thrown into jail on his first few nights on the case, by Judge Haller.In the end Vinny and his Fiancée Mona Lisa Vito recognize an error in the identification and we see Vinny shine as a lawyer.

This is one of the few movies that no one can afford to miss...Yeah, I've heard of many who didn't like the movie, didn't find it that comic or didn't like the choice for the cast. Trust me, they don't know what comedy is...The movie starts off well with no indication of what is going to happen...All part of the hilarity, the two boys (played by Ralph Macchio & Mitchell Whitfield) find themselves at the wrong side of the law. They think they have been arrested for shoplifting a can of tuna ....but the police had more sinister suspicions!!!! They desperately need a lawyer...Enter Vinny, an inexperienced lawyer played by Joe Pesci very ably portraying a New Yorker...Right from the word go, his acting is as sharp as a razor edge...The transition of Vinny from ignorance of 'procedure' to a confidence in his abilities is complete and a treat to watch. This combined with many extremely funny, embarrassing, misunderstanding, etc. moments catapult the movie to a 9 rating in my book..Much controversy has been generated on Marisa Tomei's performance & her Oscar for supporting Actress...I don't know why...Marisa gives a performance of her lifetime portraying Lisa, Vinny's girlfriend....Watch out for the deer speech and the courtroom scene right at the end....!!!

My Cousin Vinny is a very fun, well acted, entertaining film. The cast includes Marisa Tomei, Joe Pesci, Ralph macchio, and Fred Gwyne. The main thing about this film that works is the comedy and the performances by the cast that lifts up and enhances the comedic writing. Marisa Tomei is by far the best in the cast with her performance and her delivery of her lines. She deserved that academy award win. Her character is a tough, very New York woman who knows just about everything there is to know about cars. And that proves to be crucial in the court case. Joe Pesci is also very good in his role, Vincent gambini. He and Marisa have great chemistry together, whether it's in a romantic way or they're butting heads. Fred Gwyne is great as the judge, I mean could you have picked out a better more suitable fit for the overly strict judge? Who else besides Mr. Munster? The movie has well thought out pacing too, not too slow but also not too fast. It's not one sided either, it shows the point of view from Pesci and Tomei's, the judges, and Macchio and his friends. I liked that, each character got an ample amount of screen time. The ending is very clever and satisfying. Just when you think all hope is lost, Pesci comes up with a brilliant idea. 9/10.
Anyone who doesn't find this funny is missing something. Underrated script and great performances.

reviews.review_title: Funny film a classic now juggalos
reviews.content: This film I got to see in Mexico City in 92 I was on vacation from USA I went to see my family and friends and I got to see this hilarious film that now is consider a classic cult among all the media every time I see I get a good laugh out of the film is fire for comedy juggalos.

Funny film. Funny how well I'll tell you. A well written story with some funny comedy sketches, particularly when Vinnie visits his cousin in jail at the beginning. Great supporting cast and a fun film to watch.

When I first saw My Cousin Vinny, I then realized the difference in those movies that were done pre-2000, and those done today is like comparing a juicy orange to a glass of rancid milk. My Cousin Vinny was from start to finish outstanding in story line and acting. One cannot find one actor in the movie that failed in any way in his or her part. Of course Pesci was great - the woman in it, Marissa Tomei not only was quick, witty, gorgeous, but acted the part easily - and I think was the #1 actor in the movie. There's no doubt that My Cousin Vinny will be my favorite repeat picture in my library. The social conduct of Northerner or Southerner left you with a love for both (allowing that some have leanings either way). It definitely is a must see for anyone, and definitely keeps your interest from start to finish.

reviews.review_title: The clothing store has the flu and I prefer my grits al dente!
reviews.content: Sometimes you walk into a place with a swagger, a confidence. Feeling that no matter what, you have this. Personally I'm not the most presumptuous person on the planet but I recall meeting with a condominium board submitting my application for approval on a duplex. This dwelling consisted of three upstairs bedrooms, two baths, washer/dryer with backyard and front porch. I was self employed with no debts and as far as I knew the board would whisk my application through toot sweet. Three middle aged persons sat across from me. The assessors went over my application with a look of disdain. I wondered what the looks of concerns were as they gazed upon those printed sheets. After a while I said "WELL"? They pulled out my credit report and found an item from 1982 where I was late on an equipment payment that amounted to $3000.00. To my knowledge the payment was made but the bad mark stood on my record. They told me to leave the room for a decision. A few minute passed, the condo board called me in and rejected my condominium application. I was shocked , I was livid, I was beside myself. I told them there all full of S--t! This brings me to the comedy where Brooklyn meets Alabama in the Courtroom comedy My Cousin Vinny. Driving in a southerly direction Billy Gambini (Ralph Macchio) and Stan Rothenstein (Mitchell Whitfield) stop off at a convenience store to buy some snacks. They accidentally swipe an extra can of tuna as the two leave the establishment and ride of in a mint green skylark convertible. A few moments later the local police pull them over and send them to the local police station. They are questioned by Sheriff Farley (Bruce McGill)and still in the dark as what they are charged for? A stolen can of tuna perhaps? No, their charged with first degree murder for killing the shop clerk at that convenience store. Off to prison the two youths or yutes go. Billy calls his Mom with the one phone call. Billy exasperated asks his Mom, "Do we have any lawyers in the family?" Enter our colorful couple Joe Pesce as Vincent Gambini as the leather clad fledgling attorney at large and mini skirted Mona Lisa Vito (Marissa Tomei) with her fling camera always ready for a picture. The two New Yorker's step out of there car totally out of place looking for Chinese food in rural Alabama. Attorney Gambini goes to the local prison to meet his defendants. Stan never met Vinny and thought he was another inmate wanting to have relations with him until cousin Billy wakes up and explains that this is our attorney. Stanley questions his credentials which are paltry and non applicable to this case . Vincent goes on about passing the Bar exam in 6 tries with zero courtroom experience. On to the hearing where Vinny Gambini meets the prosecutor Jim Trotter (Lane Smith) and the Judge The honorable Chamberlain Haller (Fred Gwynne). Vinny seems very confident and comfortable sitting on the defendant's desk. The writer of this movie was very stringent in courtroom procedure which was very necessary in the making of the film. Vinny Gambini's abrasive behavior clashed with the Yale grad southern Judge as Vinny found himself time after time in contempt and off to prison for a good nights sleep with his defendants. Fred Gwynne plays the skeptical Judge as he constantly questions Gambini's experience or lack off. Procedure is Gambini's weakness but his he makes up for it in his aggressive questioning style in grits preparation, dirty screens and failing eye glasses. Marissa Tomei expertise in auto-motives is masterful despite being a hostile witness. Austin Pendleton adds some stuttering texture to a comedy filled trial you soon wont forget. The hysterical dialogue between Gywnne and Pesce would make a sullen John Housman crack a smile. Unfortunately this was one of Fred Gwynne's final performances as he was battling cancer and passed away a year later.

reviews.review_title: My Cousin Vinny Isn't Any Masterpiece But It Is A Great Comedy, A Fun Court Comedy Drama
reviews.content: My Cousin Vinny isn't any Masterpiece but it is a great comedy, a fun court comedy drama that perform funnily by the great Joe Pesci and delightfully by Marisa Tomei, the rest of the cast was also good, this is what makes Pesci special is that in the case of Raging Bull and Goodfellas he can be the scariest and most intense person in the room but in the case of My Cousin Vinny and another example of great comedy starring Pesci which is Home Alone he can also be the goofiest person in the room too, i have so much fun with My Cousin Vinny, i laugh a lot and i really enjoyed it.Imdb didn't let us making short review anymore. So i don't know what i'm gonna wrote except this and hey this included on the required characters so while i wrote this it's actually included and there you go!

This is my opinion. I used to watch this movie quite a bit. However, I don't now. I find Joe annoying. From his character and his clothes. It is funny in parts. Here are my problems. What makes the DA an expert on cars? Also, why does Vinny and Mona Lisa have constantly curse?! It was nice to see Marisa in a catsuit and showing her legs. That is about it. I don't think she deserved an Oscar.

This movie is hilarious and very intelligent. The dialogue is simply hysterical and is incredibly clever. The movie is about two college kids getting framed for a crime they didn't commit. Joe Pesci and Marisa Tomei star as Vinny and his girlfriend. Vinny, a cousin to one of the boys, is their only hope for escaping the death penalty-which isn't saying much because it took him six tries to pass the bar exam. At first Vinny seems like an idiot, but then slowly as the film progresses, he is proved to be extremely smart and clever. This movie has hilarious one liners and sight gags that will make you fall off your seat laughing. It's easy to see why Marisa Tomei won an Oscar.

reviews.review_title: Fish-out-of-water comedy played to great hilarity
reviews.content: An American comedy; This is a superbly crafted courtroom drama with deft comic interplay between first time lawyer Joe Pesci - an expert motormouth and street-level logician, and Marisa Tomei - a wonderfully energetic Jersey girl, feeling underappreciated, and who shows her fiancé that their parternship will be one of equality. The performances elevate a predictable script.

I've been wanting to see this movie for the longest time. It happened to come on TV today while I was channel-hopping, so I decided to finally watch it. I really enjoyed it. I didn't expect it to be so funny. Part of the hilarity was Italian-American New Yorkers, Vinny (Joe Pesci) and his fiancée Mona dealing with the Southern small town life while taking on a murder case. Vinny constantly butts heads with Judge Haller, and district attorney, Jim Trotter III.Two friends, Billy Gambini and Stan Rothenstein are driving through Alabama and stop at a convenience store. After they leave, they are soon wrongly accused with murdering the attendant. Billy calls his cousin, Vinny to try and help get him off. Vinny is a personal injury lawyer from Brooklyn, New York, newly admitted to the bar on his sixth attempt, and with no trial experience. Throughout the film, Vinny and Mona get aggravated with the small town life, Vinny will do anything and everything to help prove his innocence and even lies to the Judge about his experience as a lawyer. I highly recommend MY COUSIN VINNY!!!

reviews.review_title: A feel good movie for the acting alone!
reviews.content: Idc how much this movie makes fun of the south, everybody can have a sense of humor and good time watching it! The acting from Joe Pesci and Marisa Tomei was superb, and I even liked the performance from the grumpy judge! Sure it felt dull in a few scenes, but overall it was undoubtedly a quality early 90s movie!

I've seen a lot of movies starring Joe Pesci and I thought he did a really good job in all of them, but "My Cousin Vinny" would have to be his best. The movie stars Ralph Macchio and Mitchell Whitfield as two buddies who are on vacation, traveling through Alabama. They stop at a convenience store and buy a few things, and than they hit the road. All of a sudden there's a cop after them, and there charged for murder. O oh...what's gonna happen next? Well, Ralph has a cousin, Vinny, who's an attorney, but he's never been to court, never even been in a courtroom, and he's currently a personal-injury lawyer. Joe Pesci plays Vinny, and he shows up with his girlfriend Marisa Tomei (Mona-Lisa Veto). Marisa is hilarious too, and she even won a Best-Supporting Actress award at the Oscars. I gave this movie 10 out of 10, because this movie is hilarious, it's the best movie I've ever seen, it's one of my favourite comedies ever, and it's one of the best law-flicks ever too. So watch the movie, and see if Vinny can save the day!

A delicious courtroom comedy with fantastic performances and impeccable comedic timing. Delightful fish-out-of-water humor reigns as fresh-out-of-law-school New York lawyer Vincent Gambini (Joe Pesci) takes on the southern legal system.

I absolutely loved this movie. it was hilarious and very great. i cant get over how funny it was. when Bill and Stan are going off to collage in Alabama bill steals tuna and then after they leave, the clerk gets shot and they get accused.Joe Pecsi is Vinny and he was hilarious. so funny. my favorites were Vinny and Mona Lisa, which is Vinny's girlfriend. Mona Lisa is hilarious and i think that she deserved that Oscar. i recommend this for people who need a good laugh, or if your upset, watch it and you'll be happy again. i cant stop quoting it and i bet that u wont either if you watch it.

reviews.review_title: The court case of the century
reviews.content: My cousin Vinny is a rare treat staring Joe Pesie about a big city lawyer coming to the defense of his cousin who is on trial for murder in rural Alabama. This fish out of water tale is hilarious from the credits to the conclusion as he must try to keep his client from the electric chair, his fiancé happy and gets some rest before he loses his sanity.The humor follows his misunderstanding of how things are done in the south from the food made out of scratch, the local hicks giving him trouble over his fancy clothes and his disastrous defense technique that needs a lot of practice. What makes it heartwarming is Vinny's good nature. He dresses and acts tough but underneath the ruff exterior is a man willing to risk his reputation, freedom and relationship for those he holds dear. It shows the risks that family is willing to go for blood and nothing matters more in this world then keeping them close. Ralph Macchio, Fred Gwynne and Joe Pesci all gave Oscar worthy performances bringing their own sense of charm to the roles. The suspense was breathtaking as you wait for the verdict to be handed down and keeps you on your toes will they live or die? I found myself laughing, crying and sighing with relief all in an hour. Rent it today. Its a classic you can't miss.

If you like subtle comedies then " My Cousin Vinny" is for you. One of the best comedies that i have seen.The basic premise is simple enough. Two young guys wrongly accused of murder! What follows is a effortlessly funny effort by Joe Pesci( Vincent Gambini) to save those guys, one of them who happens to be his cousin.The highlight of the movie for me was the Awesome script and the equally extraordinary performances that the cast delivered. Joe Pesci( Gambini) was adorable and hilarious, Marisa Tomei( Mona Lisa Vito) who plays Gambini's fiancée deservingly got an Oscar for making that little role so memorable.The Judge was also great.As for the script, this movie is a perfect example of situational comedy at its best. It hooks you from the very first scene in the Shop and then what follows are little misunderstandings and small twists aided by some classy dialogues.People tend to forget Comedies over time compared to the Emotional ones. Well this movie will stay with you for this leaves a smile on your face. My all time Favorite comedy along with " Meet the Fockers" and " There is something about Mary"

There are very few comedies I find funny, if you read enough of my reviews you'll eventually find out which ones I like. This is very much one of them! For me is has everything, great acting, an excellent script and, most importantly, it's funny. But more of my thoughts later, here's a brief summary first (summary haters please consider yourselves in contempt while I write the next paragraph).Two college students, Bill Gambini and Stan Rothenstein, from Brooklyn are on their way to LA via the South when they stop off in a small town in Alabama. They are mistakenly identified as the murderers of a clerk in a small store they had visited. Unable to afford a lawyer, they turn to Bill's cousin, Vinny Gambini, who has only been practicing law for six weeks. Vinny has brought his fiancée, Mona Lisa Vito, with him but he is determined to win the case on his own. Judge Chamberlain Haller is suspicious of Vinny's credentials but allows him to defend the two boys. Vinny immediately falls fowl of the accepted procedure in court and finds himself in contempt (more than once). The prosecution seem to have a strong case but Vinny is determined to find as many holes in it as he can. Will Vinny prove the boys innocence? Will the judge discover he is only a novice? Will Vinny ever get a decent night's sleep? All these questions and many more will be answered but not here.First of all, hats off to Jonathan Lynn, I love the way he just lets the story unfold and the way he allows the characters to develop. Yes, there are one or two clunky bits, but for the most part I also very much liked the dialogue. Finally, great casting, I couldn't imagine anyone else apart from Joe Pesci playing the part of Vinny. Also, I thought Marisa Tomei was excellent as Mona Lisa Vito, a role for which she won the Best Supporting Actress Oscar, and it was great to see Fred Gwynne (yes Herman Munster) as Judge Chamberlain Haller. Honourable mentions should also go to; Ralph Macchio as Bill, Mitchell Whitfield as Stan and Lane Smith as Jim Trotter III, the prosecutor.I may be biased, but I saw this film many years ago and fell in love with it then. It's one of those I always get great pleasure from watching. If anything, it is a little long, but I can forgive that, I think when you're invested in the story the time factor becomes less important. Over all, a very well scripted film with some really great comic performances and one which I highly recommend.My score: 8.2/10

reviews.review_title: Joe Pesci delivers big laughs in this Yankee in the deep South comedy.
reviews.content: Starring: Joe Pesci, Ralph Macchio, Marisa Tomei, Fred Gwynne One of the classic tried-and-true comedy formulas is to have some sort of character mismatch. Throw one type of person or group of people in with another person or group who is totally different, and there are all sorts of things that can be done with it. My Cousin Vinny borrows this formula and does a pretty good job with it if I do say so myself.Bill Gambini (Macchio) and his friend Stan are driving back to New York, taking the scenic route through Alabama. They stop at a convenience store to get some gas and a few "groceries" for the road. Bill stuffs a can of tuna into his pocket because his arms are too full with other stuff and forgets to pay for it at the front, then they leave and get back out on the road. A few miles down the road, a cop is on their tail, the flashers go, and they get pulled over. They think it's for shoplifting the can of tuna, but little do they know that the clerk at the convenience store they were just in is now freshly murdered. So they get hauled off to jail on the assumption that it's for shoplifting a can of tuna, all the time wondering why there's such a fuss over one simple can of food.When they do eventually find out that they have been charged with murder and accessory to murder, the jaws drop and panic sets in. Bill uses his phone call to call his mom, who informs him that they have a lawyer in the family. His cousin Vinny (Pesci).So Vinny and his fiancé Mona Lisa Vito (Tomei) drive down to Alabama. Two New Yorkers clad in leather in the middle of Alabama. There's a really funny scene when Vinny goes to visit the boys in jail and Stan thinks that it's some inmate who has come to make them their sex slaves. Vinny at one point says, quote, "So let's do our best to just make this a simple in and out procedure." Sure it's a little bit dirty, but dang if it isn't funny.That's pretty much the most important plot points of the movie. The majority of the movie focuses on Vinny, who is completely inexperienced as a trial attorney, trying to win this case that could save the life of his cousin and his cousin's friend.
